messageBody:
Listers please excuse the off topic nature.

Let me reply with some examples from the manufaturing industry. Years ago
Firearms were made by artisians called gunsmiths. Each part was custom
fitted
and took many hours to make. Each firearm was different, not 'uniform'.
When
something broke then it required another artisian to repair or make a new
part.
Then Mr Whitney decided to bring 'uniformity' to the process.

Now correct me if I am wrong (I'm sure you will) but better software
development
is about

definable, documentable interfaces,
modularization,
testing ... repeatable testing,
frameworks,
patterns,
components,
automated documentation
etc.

All of these concepts drive toward 'uniform' results. Even this newsgroup's
purpose
is about promotion of software that allows repeatable testing. Better
software development
is completely about bringing 'uniformity' to the process.

If you have a definition of 'better software' then please supply it. This
definition
has to exist, otherwise, you have no standard to compare your latest project
to validate
that it is better. The feedback you are getting from this comparison will
make *gasp* your
process better!

Thank you

Michael Holly





-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
Sent: Thursday, August 21, 2003 5:05 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: OT: The goals of CMM (Re: [junit] wanted Junit professionals
urgently)


Michael Holly wrote:

> What is wrong with the concept of a defineable, repeatable, managed,
> optimized software development
> process?

Process definitions don't write software; people do.

> Where would we be if Jules Verne had not dreamed of going to the
> moon? Or Columbus
> going to the New World? Both events happened( regardless of what some
small
> fringe group say ).

I dream of someone giving me $10M, but that dream goes against basic
human nature. That is why it remains a dream.

The dreams you mention here go *with* human nature -- namely the desire
to explore -- and that helped make them happen.

> The point I'm making is that if you do not have goals then you won't get
the
> benefits of reaching
> even part of your goal.

From what I understand the goal of CMM is to define a process that even
a monkey could follow. Monkeys do not write software; people do.

> Don't get me wrong. I have been on the butt end of an Enterprise CMM
effort.
> It's mucho annoying,
> however, the underlying goal is still valid and drives toward better
> software.

It drives towards more uniform results, certainly; but I don't know
about "better software".
